Description: A pottery flask in the form of two ribbed pots with short-necked narrow mouths, slightly flaring. Their lower areas (their bases are roughly flat) are encrusted with large acanthus and plain leaves. The pots are probably miniature amphorae (although not of a well-known type), but only the outer handle in each case is modelled: from these handles floral swags droop over the amphorae, and are tied with a wide ribbon which hangs down on each side. A small naked Harpokrates sits between the jars, his finger to his mouth, holding a cornucopia to his left shoulder, and wearing a Double Crown. The rear is unmodelled, except for a small pierced suspension-lug immediately behind Harpokrates. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt, with a little mica; overall slip of much the same colour: perhaps related to Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased. Ptolemaic, probably second or first century BC. Comparanda: Similar in shape, but plainer: Edgar 1911: pl. xxvi:26296, from Memphis. Near: Vogt 1924: pl. xx:3; Perdrizet 1921: no. 83 = LIMC iv (2): pl. 256, Harpokrates 253. Bibliog: Pagenstecher 1913: 80, fig. 93; Hayes 1997: pl. 27, thought to be Memphis Ware and possibly early Roman.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3656)
Hayes 1997 / Handbook of Mediterranean Roman pottery (pl.27)
